title-group.article-title: Quality of the Finnish Hospital Discharge Register: A systematic review

contrib-group.aff: National Institute for Health and Welfare, Helsinki, Finland

author-notes.corresp: Reijo Sund, National Institute for Health and Welfare, PO Box 30, FI-00271 Helsinki, Finland. E-mail: reijo.sund@thl.fi

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 the Nordic Societies of Public Health
permissions.copyright-holder: Associations of Public Health in the Nordic Countries Regions

abstract.p: Aims: The Finnish Hospital Discharge Register (FHDR) is one of the oldest individual level hospital discharge registers and has been intensively used for research purposes. The aim of this study was to gather information concerning the quality of FHDR into one place in terms of a systematic review of validation studies that compare data to external information. Methods: Several reference databases were searched for validity articles published until January 2012. For each included study, focus of validation, register years examined, number of compared observations, external source(s) of data, summary of validation results, and conclusions concerning the validity of FHDR were extracted. Results: In total, 32 different studies comparing FHDR data to external information were identified. Most of the studies examined validity in the case of vascular disease, mental disorders or injuries. More than 95% of discharges could be identified from the register. Positive predictive value (PPV) for common diagnoses was between 75 and 99%. Conclusions: Completeness and accuracy in the register seem to vary from satisfactory to very good in the register as long as the recognised limitations are taking into account. Poor recording of subsidiary diagnoses and secondary operations and other rarely used items are the most obvious limitations in validity, but do not compromise the value of data in FHDR in being used in studies that are not feasible to conduct otherwise.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Administrative register data has been recognised to be a feasible and cost-effective way to study large, possibly nationwide, populations. The main disadvantage of such data is the secondary nature, i.e. that the data have not been collected primarily for the purposes of specific research question [1], and therefore that the quality of the data for the intended research purpose is unknown [2].

The Finnish Hospital Discharge Register (FHDR) is one of the oldest individual level hospital discharge registers covering the whole country in the world. FHDR contains nationwide linkable data on all inpatient hospital discharges with personal identification code since 1969, while corresponding registers in Sweden [3] and Denmark [4] have had similar nationwide linkable data since 1987 and 1977. FHDR has been intensively used in health research and most studies consider its quality to be good. This indicates high validity, as the quality must have been at least implicitly assessed in each study, even though the actual evaluation process is not usually reported explicitly. More specific information concerning the quality of data items in the FHDR seems, however, to be fragmented and difficult to find. The aim of this study was to gather information concerning the quality of FHDR into one place in terms of a systematic review of validation studies that utilise external information.

sec.title: Finnish Hospital Discharge Register
sec.p: FHDR has a long history. Since 1956 various kinds of samples have been collected, and since 1967 full nationwide collection has been continuous (Table I [7–15]). About the same time, the personal identity code was introduced in Finland [5]. The Finnish PIC consists of date of birth (DDMMYY), a separator digit that tells the century of the birth (+, 19th; –, 20th; A, 21st), a running number for persons with the same date of birth (odd, male; even, female), and a check digit calculated with a modulo-31 algorithm [6]. PICs have been recorded in the FHDR since 1969, and data since that year are easily accessible nowadays in a computerised form.

caption.p: Timeline of the Finnish Hospital Discharge Register.

tr.td: Three separate month-long pilot collections of data from all hospitals
Nationwide pilot collection of all hospital inpatient discharges for the whole year [7,8]
Various samples, since 1963 data about patients staying in the mental hospitals over the turn of the year
Full nationwide collection of all hospital inpatient discharges [9,10]
Personal identity codes, ICD-8 classification of diagnoses
Registers for general hospitals and tuberculosis sanatoriums combined
Data about all patients staying in the hospitals over the turn of the year (collected also for the years 1986 and 1991) [11]
All hospital types in one discharge register [11], operations recorded using the classification of Finnish Hospital League

Name of the register changed to the Finnish Health Care Register [13], data about all patients staying in the hospitals over the turn of the year, extra data sheet for coronary patients, selected day-surgical procedures
Discharges from social welfare institutions [14], extra data sheet for psychiatric patients [15], HILMO-scale reporting the estimated need for care
ICD-10 classification of diagnoses, the Finnish version of Nomesko procedure classification (introduced in the middle of year), all day-surgical procedures recorded
Outpatient visits in hospitals (and possibility to report more diagnoses and operations than before)
Extra variables for recording adverse effects

sec.p: The basic variables collected in the register include PIC (including date of birth and sex), area of residence, hospital ID, admission and discharge days, and diagnoses of patient’s medical problems. In most other variables, there have been some changes over the years. In the beginning, there were separate registers with slightly different data sheets for different types of hospitals (general/tuberculosis/psychiatric/other), but those are now combined into one register (Table I).

Diagnoses were recorded using the ICD-8 during 1969–1986, ICD-9 during 1987–1995, and ICD-10 since 1996. Operations were registered using the classification of the National League of Hospitals during 1986–1996, and from 1996 onwards using the Finnish version of Nomesko procedure classification has been used (in 1996 both classifications were used).

Before the era of electronic information systems, the disharge data was collected using data sheets for each discharge. In 1976, a regional system for discharge handling was launched, i.e. each central hospital district created computerised file of discharges of hospitals in their region before sending it to the central register once a year. There is systematic internal quality control for the register data. Certain logical errors are algorithmically checked and the data collection clerk reviews the contents of the data, compares the changes with earlier years and asks hospitals to correct detected errors.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Basic data concerning the numbers of records and proportions of correct PICs in the FHDR were calculated from the raw register data. For the purposes of systematic review, we searched PUBMED, Scopus, CSA, and ISI Web of Knowledge as well as the Finnish Medic and ARTO databases for articles published until January 2012 using the following query: (finland or finnish) and (register* or registry or “information system” or “routine data” or “administrative data”) and (quality or valid* or completeness or coverage or accuracy) and (discharge or FHDR or “health care”)

Titles and abstracts were screened and potentially relevant papers were obtained. Reference lists of the obtained articles were searched by hand for additional relevant material. Finally, full texts of more than 150 potentially relevant papers were obtained. Each study was classified to one or more of the following five groups: (1) external validity studies with main focus on FHDR; (2) external validity studies with main focus not on FHDR; (3) internal validity studies; (4) studies having only a minor focus on validation; and (5) descriptive or non-FHDR related studies.

For each study in category 1, focus of validation, register years examined, number of compared observations, external source(s) of data, summary of validation results, and conclusions concerning the validity of FHDR were extracted. Studies were extremely heterogeneous in terms of methodology.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: PIC was rarely registered correctly during the first years of FHDR (Table II), and the use of pseudo-PIC consisting of the date of birth (DDMMYY), initials (two uppercase letters), and sex (1 for men and 2 for women) was common. At the end of 1971, hospitals were instructed to always include PIC in the discharge abstracts, and the proportion of correctly recorded PIC increased to 85% in 1972 (Table II). Since then, the proportion of correctly recorded PICs systematically increased until reaching more than 99% in the early 1990s. During the years 2006–2010, newborns explained about a quarter, and foreigners about 40% of the remaining errors, i.e. almost two-thirds of the errors were due to treated persons who had not a PIC. The relatively high proportion of temporary PICs during the years 1995–2000 were mainly due to newborns, as some hospital information systems had automatically created syntactically correct temporary PICs for them.

caption.p: Correct personal identity codes (PICs) in the Finnish Hospital Discharge Register 1969–2010.

fn.p: Error 1, incomplete or syntactically erroneous PIC; error 2, syntactically correct temporary PIC (running number begins with 9).

sec.p: There were in total 32 studies that fitted the inclusion criteria for category 1, i.e. external validity studies with main focus on FHDR (Supplementary Table, available online) [16–57]. Virtually all studies validated only the inpatient discharges from the hospitals and health centres. Seven of the studies consisted of more than one publication, typically because of separate reports in Finnish and in English. Only a few studies aimed to say something general about the completeness of FHDR by comparing the hospital-specific numbers of registered discharges to the numbers found from the annual reports of the hospitals [43,44,53,54] or about the accuracy by comparing data in a random sample (stratified by hospital type) of all discharges to the corresponding data in medical records of the same patients [17,18].

Most of the studies examined validity in the case of vascular disease (12), mental disorders (10), or injuries (6) (Table III). Studies mainly focused on only one disease group and performed validation following the simple epidemiological approach, i.e. by checking that certain disease cases could be completely and accurately identified from the register. Only a few studies had somewhat different approach; one evaluated the suitability of several FHDR data items to performance assessment purposes [55] and another assessed the use of need-for-care scale in FHDR in efficiency measurements [19].

caption.p: Validation of diagnoses and coverage in the Finnish Hospital Discharge Register.

tr.td: Confirmed diagnoses in a genetic study
Leprosy, yellow fever, trachoma, syphilis tarda [43]

Infections, neoplasms, endocrine diseases, blood diseases, diseases of the nervous, respiratory, digestive, and genitourinary systems, complications of pregnancy and childbirth, diseases of the skin and the musculoskeletal system, congenital anomalies, normal delivery, alcoholism [17,18]

fn.label: a
fn.p: Coverage of hospitalisations. bAmong three registers. cSchizophrenia only.MR, medical records.

sec.p: The coverage of register, i.e. the percentage of persons (or hospitalisations) that could be identified from the FHDR, was generally reported to be more than 80% (Table III). By focusing on hospitalised patients and more recent years, the gaps caused by patients without hospitalisations or records with incorrectly recoded PICs disappeared, and reported coverage rose to above 95%.

Almost every study evaluated the accuracy of diagnosis. Sensitivity, i.e. true-positive rate, was seldom reported as its calculation requires the number of false-negative cases, which varied a lot between diseases (Table III). The positive predictive value (PPV), i.e. proportion of register-detected cases that were confirmed to be true-positives according to the external data, could be derived from several studies even though it was not always reported or called PPV. For common diagnoses, PPV varied between 75 and 99%, but for rare diseases false-positives were much more likely. Clear recording errors, i.e. false-positives that were not related to uncertainty in clinical diagnoses, seemed to be quite rare.

Majority of the studies concluded that the quality of FHDR was good or at least satisfactory (Supplementary Table). None of the studies found the quality of FHDR to be poor in general, but important restrictions to be kept in mind were reported. Poor recording of subsidiary diagnoses, including the external causes, is one severe limitation of the FHDR. In any case, the use of FHDR data required a critical approach and sensitivity to detect and deal with potential problems.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, the quality of FHDR was evaluated based on published validation studies in scientific literature. This approach made it feasible to capture quality evaluations that had received enough attention to be published as a separate paper or as a significant part of the paper. Some small-scale, non-published or grey-literature studies may be missing from the review, especially if none of the included studies have had references to them. This review also focuses to scientific literature and therefore to the secondary use of the FHDR. In this sense, health policy aspects and visions that have had huge effects on the decisions on the primary collection of register data are likely to be underrepresented, although such viewpoints include very useful information for researchers who plan to utilise the FHDR [10,58–60].

In addition, quite strict inclusion criteria (to studies that focus on validating the register data to some external data) were used in this review, and therefore some validation studies (using only internal checks) or studies that included relevant validation results (not primarily concerning the FHDR or had only a minor role in the publication) were excluded from the data extraction phase. For example, there is one comprehensive early example of systematic checking of internal consistency of FHDR concerning the years 1969–1975 [61], some reports on the discharge data development projects [62,63] and on the impact of new classification of diagnoses on discharge data [64], and more recent critical reports on poor recording of diagnoses of mental retardation [65], waiting times [66], subsidiary diagnoses [67], external cause codes [68], and adverse effects [69]. Also studies commenting the quality of data about patients discharged from or staying in at the turn of the year in social welfare care institutions were excluded [70,71].

Another type of excluded studies including interesting information validated other registers with the help of FHDR. Examples are studies concerning the sterilisation register [72,73], cancer registry [74,75], malformation register [76], arthoplasty register [77,78], and vascular registries [79,80]. One similar type of studies concerns data sets derived from several registers including the FHDR. Some examples deal with databases for breast cancer [81], cardiovascular diseases [82], diabetes [83], and intellectual disabilities [84].

Also some studies that reported validation results very briefly (before more comprehensive validation studies) were excluded [85–88]. In addition, one typical way of using FHDR data has been to identify the patient population from the register and then obtain medical records of the patients as a primary source of data. Such studies probably quite often report at least the percentage of correctly diagnosed patients in the FHDR compared to case records [89–91], but these kind of studies are, unfortunately, difficult to identify from the literature in a systematic way.

One potentially quite useful group of excluded studies contains studies that have used local discharge register rather than FHDR. This type of studies dealt with coronary heart disease [92,93], mental disorders [94–98], and accidents or surgical care [99–101].

It is well known that the validity of the data depend on the intended use [2]. Most studies evaluated the validity of FHDR from the epidemiological perspective, although in conclusions it was quite often stated that data were also suitable for (end point assessment in) health services research. It is usually rather straightforward to evaluate validity from this kind of simple epidemiological perspective, but may become much more complicated for other purposes such as performance assessment [55]. It is also obvious that certain variables are easier to measure and compare than others that may reflect phenomena that have no golden standard for measurement. The measurement properties may also vary within variables; for example, the diagnosis of hip fracture using X-rays is much more straightforward than the diagnosis of some mental disorder such as schizophrenia [1].

Completeness in the FHDR was found to be very good. If all discharges of patients with false-negative diagnosis or operation code in FHDR are taken into account, it seems that (nowadays) virtually all inpatient discharges from Finnish hospitals can be found from the FHDR. There is not much information available concerning the completeness of hospital outpatient visits, although psychiatric outpatient visits are known to contain obvious gaps (varying by hospital and time). It is also known that in the case of certain small (day surgical) operations (due to e.g. cataract or hallux valgus), some cases from the private clinics, which can also be identified from the reimbursement register of Social Insurance Institution, are missing erroneously from the FHDR. In addition, one known significant gap in the recent years is that all data from the central military hospital during its final year of existence (2005) are missing from the FHDR.

One limitation of the FHDR from the epidemiological perspective is that only patients treated in inpatient ward or in hospital are included in the register, and the key issue in validity of many epidemiological studies examining incidence or prevalence is how completely possible it is to capture people who qualify for the diagnosis of interest. In principle, this is not an indication of bad quality of the register per se, but reflects the incompatibility between the research objective and secondary data. Such incompatibility could be corrected by including also missing (outpatient) services to the register.

However, even for identification of disease groups known to be virtually always treated in hospital, such as hip fractures, there may be challenges for incidence or end-point calculations. There may of course be some false-negatives, possibly due to clear errors in registration, but non-erroneous false-positives seem to be a bigger nuisance. For example, the diagnosis in FHDR should describe why the patient was treated or examined even if it had turned out that the suspected condition, such as hip fracture or narcolepsy, was not the actual reason for the symptoms. In such cases, the FHDR diagnosis is correct in the sense of resource usage, but does not reflect confirmed disease of the patient. Another, and much bigger, source for non-erroneous false-positives are (re)hospitalisations of the same patient due to the same (non-chronic) disease entity. It may be challenging to deal with such problems appropriately [102].

Although the perspectives for validation of data in FHDR have been quite narrow, the conclusions from the validation studies are highly relevant for all studies utilising the FHDR. By the end of 1980s there are no more technical errors in the register, and completeness and accuracy in the register seem to be from satisfactory to very good in the register as long as the recognised limitations are taken into account. Poor recording of subsidiary diagnoses and operations and other rarely used items are the most obvious limitations in validity, but do not compromise the value of data in FHDR to be used in studies that are not feasible to conduct otherwise. These conclusions are similar to a study that reviewed validation studies of Swedish national inpatient register [3].

In addition to validation studies, a reasonable measure of quality of register is the common use of its data in scientific studies, as each properly performed study should have been critical in the use of register-based data. In the case of FHDR, there are hundreds of published studies in respected scientific journals and it would have been unfeasible to check all of them for comments on validity. For the same reason, suggestions to improve the FHDR were not systematically extracted in this review. However, some common wishes concerning the FHDR include new variables or better recording of extra diagnosis or operation codes that would, for example, indicate the side of operation and whether the treatment was for a new disorder and give the possibility to describe reoperations or complications taking place during the same hospitalisation, provide more variables for diagnoses of comorbid conditions present at admission (as in some countries) and other risk factors such as smoking and body mass index, record data on quality of life and functional disability, on medication during hospitalisation and on laboratory results, routinely link the causes of death register to FHDR, and record data on (primary care) outpatient visits in private and occupational health care.

It is also probable that much of important information concerning the validity of FHDR for various purposes exits only in the form of tacit knowledge of researchers who have utilised the data. For example, operation codes in the FHDR may in some cases be in an arbitrary order because of compromises made while transforming data from the hospitals’ information systems, and therefore it is probably invalid to separate primary and other operations using such named fields in the FHDR. It is also known that there may be some artificial discharge/admission pairs in the register meaning that there is discharge for virtually all patients in one institution at the same day and “new” admission on the following day. Reasons for such minor anomalies are typically changes in local service organisation or information systems. In one large project, which utilised FHDR extensively, it was detected that primary diagnoses were mixed up in 2005 data in one hospital district. Data from that hospital district was requested again and problem was corrected with an extra update to the FHDR in 2009.

While using the data from FHDR, or any other secondary data source, there is no one best methodological way to do it. The value of secondary data to solve a research question should always be assessed separately with an extra interpretation and operationalisation phases [1]. Such intelligent preprocessing of data by enriching it with background information is inevitable but very challenging and time consuming [1,102]. Data in FHDR are also so unique that there may not be ready-made methodological solutions to utilise it in exceptional ways [60,103]. It is typical that data from FHDR is linked with data from several other registers in order to build comprehensive research databases [104–106]. The good quality of data in the FHDR is essential also for these databases to provide excellent opportunities for research now and in the future.

ack.p: The author would like to thank Mr Simo Pelanteri for providing data for Table II.
